All IRS employees who request engineering services.
Table of Contents
Overview of Engineering Program

) This IRM provides an overview of the responsibilities that Engineering employees should understand and apply in the performance of their duties. and The primary objective of the IRS Engineering Program is to support the mission of the IRS and LB&I. (

) IRS engineers provide professional and accurate development of issues as well as efficient and effective resolutions to more complex engineering and valuation issues. Engineers provide expertise to issues encountered in all types of tax returns. The Engineering Program is committed to providing trained, knowledgeable and effective members to the examination team. Engineering Program also has a key role in the Outside Expert Program. (

) Audience: All IRS employees who request engineering services. Engineers support all IRS organizations that examine tax returns and provide direct support to non-examination organizations, such as Appeals, Counsel, Investigation, Collection and the Department of Justice. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Eastern Compliance Practice Area (
) Program Owner: Director of Field Operations (DFO), Engineering (

) Engineering services are available in several areas of expertise, including with advanced degrees, professional designations, and state certiﬁcations/ licenses. The following is a list of engineering specialists working in the Engineering Program: • General Engineer (GS-
) • Mining Engineer (GS-
) • Petroleum Engineer (GS-
) • Industrial Engineer (GS-
) • Internal Revenue Agent Valuation Specialist (GS-
) • Financial Analyst/Intangible Property Appraiser (GS-
) • Real Property Appraiser (GS-
) • Personal Property Appraiser (GS-
) All of the above specialists are hereafter referred to as “engineers” or neering specialists”. (

) The Engineering Program typically provides expertise to local geographic pliance practice areas; however, engineers with specialized issue training assist other geographic practice areas. Engineering issues include:
Mining Engineer (GS-
) Petroleum Engineer (GS-
) Industrial Engineer (GS-

Engineering (
) By law, the Service has the authority to conduct examinations under Title Internal Revenue Code, Subtitle F – Procedure and Administration,
, Discovery of Liability and Enforcement of Title, Subchapter A, and Inspection, which includes, but is not limited to, the following IRC • IRC
, Examination of books and witnesses • IRC
, Time and place of examination For additional information see IRM
, Examination of Returns, and
, LB&I Examination Process (

) The Engineering Program consists of a director of ﬁeld operations (DFO), gineering, territory managers, program analysts, team managers and The DFO, Engineering reports to the Eastern Compliance Practice Area director. The engineering teams are located across the United States. LB&I organization Chart.pdf. (
) The DFO, Engineering provides management oversight on all aspects of Engineering Program, including budget and staffing. of (

) The DFO, Engineering ensures that the program addresses: • Policy and legislative changes • Uniform and consistent treatment of issues • Timely and professional technical assistance • Trends and developing issues (

) Management of the Engineering Program includes: • Determining budget, staffing, and training • Developing measures to gauge and monitor program effectiveness • Monitoring management information systems • Conducting program visits to territories • Coordinating national projects • Developing and recommending referral criteria • Developing position descriptions • Maintaining a directory of Engineering personnel and related (
) The DFO, Engineering oversees design and delivery of engineering Training in the Engineering Program includes Continuing Professional Education (CPE), Recruit Training and Out-service Training. (

) The DFO, Engineering provides oversight by: • Issuing guidelines and procedures • Assisting territories in achieving uniform program direction • Providing technical and administrative assistance when necessary • Resolving differences between territories • Resolving differences between Engineering and other divisions • Providing liaison between ﬁeld and national functions (
) The DFO, Engineering communicates directly with Engineering territory managers and Engineer team managers when necessary.
The DFO, Engineering provides management oversight on all aspects of the Engineering Program, including budget and staffing.
The DFO, Engineering communicates directly with Engineering territory managers and Engineer team managers when necessary.
of Engineering Program

) The DFO, Engineering represents the Engineering Program to the Eastern Compliance Practice Area director by: • Presenting support for staffing needs • Providing data to support budgetary requests and needs • Participating in strategic planning • Describing new tax issues that may impact the Engineering • Advocating training needs of all types (
) The DFO, Engineering represents the Engineering Program to external holders such as appraisal and valuation societies, associations of tax personnel, and other professional societies. (
) Territory managers directly supervise engineer team managers. The managers perform operational reviews of engineer team managers. Engineering (
) Territory managers ensure that appropriate resources are assigned to including resources in other Engineering territories. (
) Territory managers recommend policy changes and procedures to the Engineering. (

) Territory managers, engineering program analysts, and the DFO, work as a team to ensure that the Engineering Program functions and effectively. This team considers and recommends changes in policy or procedure to improve the overall effectiveness of the Engineering Program. (
) Territory managers perform periodic workload reviews to provide current staffing needs to the DFO, Engineering. (
) Territory managers oversee travel, supplies, training, Outside Expert (IRM
, Outside Expert Program) and other budgetary issues for respective territories. (
) Territory managers work with practice area territory managers to resolve ences as necessary. (
) Territory managers participate in Engineering Program work groups and program initiatives. (
) Territory managers serve as acting DFO, Engineering when necessary. (
) The engineering program analyst supports the DFO, Engineering and managers to facilitate the implementation and completion of program Engineering tives and initiatives. (
) The engineering program analyst works with analysts from other practice areas. (

) The engineering team manager is responsible for the overall management, erations, and quality of the work product of the Engineering Program at the Engineering examination team level. The engineering team manager’s responsibilities include: • Receiving, prioritizing, and timely processing all requests for ing services. (

(

) With respect to Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) examinations, the engi- neering team manager’s involvement includes: • Review and approve the engineer’s risk analysis and audit plan. • Attend opening conferences of LB&I team examinations, when ate. • Assist the practice area team manager in creating a team • Coordinate work scheduling and monitor progress of audit with engineer, team coordinator and case manager. • Assist in issue development as necessary. • Attend status meetings as requested by the taxpayer, engineer, or manager. • Participate in issue discussions with the engineer, team coordinator or case manager. • Attempt to resolve issues at the earliest point possible in the examina- tion. • Participate in issue resolution discussions with the case manager. • Provide feedback on audit and LB&I team process. • Participate in resolution of differences. • Assist the examination team if the team believes that an outside would be useful to the examination. • For additional roles and responsibilities see IRM
, Issue Manager Roles and Responsibilities, and IRM
, Managers Team Members Who Are Not Designated as the Case Manager or Manager. (
) The engineering team manager will ensure that all engineers assigned to LCC examination are familiar with the roles and responsibilities of the team members as speciﬁed in IRM
, Roles and Responsibilities. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The engineering team manager will ensure that all engineers assigned to any LCC examination are familiar with the roles and responsibilities of the various team members as speciﬁed in IRM 4.46.1.1.3, Roles and Responsibilities.
Overview of Engineering Program

IRM 4.46, LB&I Examination Process (LEP), provides speciﬁc procedures for preparation of the plan, development of issues, and issue resolution. Some of the responsibilities of the engineering team manager with respect to the LEP include:
a. Planning the examination (IRM

) -- The engineering team manager will coordinate with the case manager on the Issue Selection and Col- laboration Process and the Specialist Initial Risk Assessment. They will also participate with the case manager in the initial survey establishing the breadth and depth of the scope, as well as potential issues pertaining to the specialty area. If time does not permit personal involvement with the case manager, the engineering team manager should nevertheless participate and approve, in writing, the planned recommendations of the assigned engineer. b. Executing the examination (IRM

) – The engineering team manager will monitor the progress of the examination by periodically having discussions with the engineer. Because engineers usually have several assignments, the engineering team manager will establish the priority of work based on the status of case, signiﬁcance of potential issues, etc., and advise the case manager. The engineering team manager will be available to discuss with the case manager any matters or questions regarding the effectiveness of the examination pro- cedures, including the information document request (IDR) process and the acknowledgment of facts (AOF) IDR for potentially unagreed issues. The engineering team manager will also make job-site visits to monitor the performance of the engineer in selected cases. This activity should be coordinated with the case manager. c. Resolution of the examination (IRM

) –The engineering team manager will participate with the case manager and the engineer in meetings with the taxpayer to discuss and attempt to resolve issues, which are complex or have substantial tax or compliance impact. The en- gineering team manager will review and approve the engineer’s report prior to submitting it to the case manager.
Engineers receive referrals from LB&I and other organizations:
(09-23-2020) Role of the Engineering Specialist
The engineer is a member of the issue team. The roles and responsibilities of the engineer as an LB&I team member are deﬁned in IRM
, Team Member Roles and Responsibilities. The engineer also works with referring agents or estate and gift tax attorneys to develop and present issues to the taxpayer.
Roles and responsibilities of the engineering specialist include:

Engineering • Coordinate with team coordinator. • Review relevant information such as tax returns, public information, studies, etc. • Collaborate with the revenue agent to complete a Collaboration ment Matrix (CAM). A CAM is required for non-LCC cases and recommended for all other cases. • Perform a risk/trend analysis. • Hold issue discussions with the taxpayer. • Draft an audit plan. • Get engineering manager approval of risk analysis and audit plan. • Conduct the examination of issue (i.e., prepare IDRs, conduct inter- views, perform site visits, etc.) to determine the proper tax treatment. • Continuously risk assess and amend the scope of the issue as new facts are developed. • Draft a work product if adjustments are warranted and discuss with issue team and issue manager. (See IRM

for a discussion engineer work products.) • Present ﬁndings to the taxpayer. • Resolve issue if possible or support alternative issue resolution. • Maintain workpapers contemporaneously either in paper copy or tronically in the Issue Management System (IMS). (

) When providing assistance to Appeals, Counsel, Criminal Investigation, the S. Department of Justice, or other non-examination referrals, the engineer provide expert advice, an expert report and expert testimony as required to assist the referring party. This expertise could involve: • Assistance with determining the correct treatment of items on a tax return. • Valuation assistance, including an appraisal of tangible property or valuation of a business interest or intangible property. • Other assistance, including technical engineering or scientiﬁc or expertise as may beneﬁt the speciﬁc case. (
) Before written products prepared by the engineer are submitted to the requestor, the engineering team manager will review both issue narratives expert reports. (

) Program Goals: The goal of the Engineering Program is to deliver timely, fectively planned, and properly managed support of examinations of tax and providing for quality results and minimization of burden to the IRS and to taxpayers. (

) Program Reports: The Engineering Program collects issue examination time utilization data documentation and monitors the progress and results assigned issues through various information management systems. (

) Program Effectiveness: The effectiveness of the Engineering Program is monitored by issue examination and time utilization information system mentation and reporting, time entry system reporting, and other sources of information. Effectiveness is determined by the Program whereby mission program objectives are accomplished efficiently, and reliable information is obtained and used for decision making. Statutes and regulations are to ensure the Program’s resources are protected from mismanagement and misappropriation of funds. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
Z

Program Effectiveness: The effectiveness of the Engineering Program is monitored by issue examination and time utilization information system docu

mentation and reporting, time entry system reporting, and other sources of information. Effectiveness is determined by the Program whereby mission and program objectives are accomplished efficiently, and reliable information is obtained and used for decision making. Statutes and regulations are followed to ensure the Program’s resources are protected from mismanagement and misappropriation of funds.
Overview of Engineering Program

IRM
Real Property Valuation Guidelines (

) The Engineering Program encourages referrals. Tax returns may be referred engineering assistance is appropriate. Examiners should make referrals as for early as possible upon identiﬁcation of an issue involving a specialist. A issue review and assessment by Engineering is available to determine if a referral is warranted. Such cases will use Miscellaneous Examination Activity Codes as deﬁned by IRM
and applied by engineering specialists in ac- cordance with the Engineering Issue Management System (IMS) and Timekeeping Desk Guide. (

) A referral to MITRE could be considered if research credit contains internal software (IUS) qualiﬁed research expenses (QREs). Referral and/or consulta- tion requests to MITRE can also be made if QREs are below the threshold at the discretion of the issue team. The MITRE referral form is available here: https://portal.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/vl
/Credits/MITRERe
orm%
pdf. (
) For art appraisals greater than $
, referral is mandatory and must be sent directly to the National Office Art Appraisal Services. See IRM
, Referrals of Artwork to Art Appraisal Services and the Art Advisory Panel. (
) For appraisals of art and collectibles less than $
see IRM

, Valuation Assistance for Cases Involving Works of Art, for referral procedures to request art valuation assistance. The engineering team manager will determine which engineering specialist to assign. (

) The Specialist Referral System (SRS) is the preferred method for making referrals for engineering services from SB/SE, TE/GE and for LCC inventory LB&I. LB&I should use the MIRA/SIRA process for other inventory. The recipient of the referral is usually the local engineer team manager. If a post duty has more than one engineer team manager, the Engineering territory manager may determine the recipient. (

) Generally, all LCC referrals will be assigned to one or more engineers who perform risk analyses and, if appropriate, prepare audit plans for submission the LCC team. The engineer team manager will evaluate non-LCC referrals and requests for assistance from other divisions or organizations (e.g., W&I, E&G, etc.) before the requests are assigned to an engineer. (

) Engineering may request additional information to determine whether ing assistance is needed. Further, some or all the following information may necessary before the engineer team manager can determine the level of neering assistance. a. Copy of the face of the tax return b. Copies of the balance sheet, Schedule M-
, Schedule M-
, and M-

g. Location of property h. Location of books and records i. Source of referral if not from LB&I j. Copies of appraisals, sales documents, leases, etc. k. Studies prepared by the taxpayer or their representative (
) Within

calendar days of receipt of the referral, the engineer team will inform the requestor that the referral was received. The engineer team manager will assign or reject the referral as soon as practical with the goal

calendar days or less. For non-LCC referrals, additional material may be necessary for the engineer team manager to make an informed decision the referral. If the additional information is not received timely, the engineer team manager may assign an engineer to the referral to meet the SRS disposition requirement. (

) Engineer team managers are responsible for locating the most appropriate resources for each referral. This resource could be a local engineer, an engineer at another location, an outside expert, or a combination of these options. An SRS referral may be transferred to another engineering team. (
) The referring examiner should assist the assigned engineer in obtaining necessary data or records from the taxpayer and other sources. See IRM
, Planning the Examination, for information on the speciﬁc procedures for participating in LB&I examinations as members of the issue team. (

) To determine the scope of the examination, the engineer must participate in planning process with the referring agent/attorney or with the audit team. factors considered must meet the requirements of applicable law, and IRS policy. See IRM
Examination of Returns and IRM
, LB&I amination Process. (

) Communication, teamwork, and documentation are essential. The engineer communicate on a regular basis with other team members and with the taxpayer. The engineer will contact the requestor at least once every

and document activity or include any reasons for inactivity. The engineer papers will contain the necessary documentation of the examination work performed. The engineer will follow all relevant procedures for third party contacts. The engineer will seek agreement with the issue team on total planned examination time and starting and completion dates. The manager must approve all days allotted and the issue completion date. (
) After receiving the case assignment, the engineer will perform a risk with the referring agent/attorney or issue team (IRM

). The engineer conduct and document the risk analysis regardless of the type of or source of referral. The engineer team manager will review and approve risk analysis. For more information concerning risk analysis, see IRM
, Risk Analysis, and IRM
, Risk Analysis Process. (

) Any large, unusual, and questionable (LUQ) items identiﬁed will depend on engineer’s judgment of the return and the separate items that comprise the return. Some factors to be considered when identifying these items are: • Taxpayer’s history on the issue • Trend analysis of current and prior tax years • Comparative size of the item Internal Revenue Manual
of Engineering Program 4.48.1

The referring examiner should assist the assigned engineer in obtaining necessary data or records from the taxpayer and other sources. See IRM 4.46.3., Planning the Examination, for information on the speciﬁc procedures for participating in LB&I examinations as members of the issue team.

amination Process. Communication, teamwork, and documentation are essential. The engineer will communicate on a regular basis with other team members and with the taxpayer. The engineer will contact the requestor at least once every

days and document activity or include any reasons for inactivity. The engineer work- papers will contain the necessary documentation of the examination work performed. The engineer will follow all relevant procedures for third party contacts. The engineer will seek agreement with the issue team on total planned examination time and starting and completion dates. The engineering manager must approve all days allotted and the issue completion date.
Taxpayer’s history on the issue Trend analysis of current and prior tax years Comparative size of the item

Engineering • Absolute size of the item • Inherent character of the item • Potential impact to current tax (e.g. carryforward research credit) • Timing or permanent tax issue • Application of new tax law or regulations • Relationship to other items • Whipsaw issues • Automatic adjustments • Missing items (

) Regardless of the type or class of return, the engineer should ﬁrst review the return in its entirety. This review should include the line items and credits claimed. Balance sheets, elections, schedules, or any other documents attached to the return are included in the review. The review also should include any relevant items from other sources. (

) As part of the risk analysis, the engineer should compare the potential from examining a return to the resources required to perform the examination. After the potential beneﬁts and resources are considered, the engineer will rank the issues in priority order. Generally, the engineer will examine the issues with higher audit potential before those with lower potential. The engineer team manager may request the engineer to reprioritize based on other factors. (

) The engineer should review all LUQ items. However, the engineer cannot examine every possible issue. For instance, it is not proper for the engineer make a detailed analysis, unless the potential adjustments will materially the tax liability or will be important from a compliance viewpoint. The engineer is expected to adequately explain both examined items and the large, or questionable items that are accepted without examination. The case ﬁle workpapers must clearly indicate the scope of the examination for each issue, the depth of the examination, and the reasons for the tax determination reached. (

) The audit plan should contain a description of the issue(s), anticipated audit steps needed, additional resources needed (such as outside experts, sampling coordinator, overnight travel, etc.), estimated issue completion date, and estimated days needed to complete the examination. The engineer team manager must approve the audit plan prior to submission to the referring agent/attorney or issue team. (

) The scope of the examination may be expanded or reduced during the nation as facts develop on the issue. If additional time is requested by the engineer, approval by the engineer manager is needed. If the estimated completion date or the statute needs an extension, issue manager and case manager approval is needed. Extending the statute may also require territory manager concurrence. (

) If a new engineering issue is identiﬁed during the examination, a new risk analysis must be completed by the engineer and approved by the engineering team manager. The engineering team manager will coordinate with the case manager to get the issue added in IMS.

) The engineer should review all LUQ items. However, the engineer cannot examine every possible issue. For instance, it is not proper for the engineer to make a detailed analysis, unless the potential adjustments will materially affect the tax liability or will be important from a compliance viewpoint. The engineer is expected to adequately explain both examined items and the large, unusual, or questionable items that are accepted without examination. The case ﬁle and workpapers must clearly indicate the scope of the examination for each issue, the depth of the examination, and the reasons for the tax determination reached. (

) The audit plan should contain a description of the issue(s), anticipated audit steps needed, additional resources needed (such as outside experts, statistical sampling coordinator, overnight travel, etc.), estimated issue completion date, and estimated days needed to complete the examination. The engineer team manager must approve the audit plan prior to submission to the referring agent/attorney or issue team. (

) The scope of the examination may be expanded or reduced during the exami- nation as facts develop on the issue. If additional time is requested by the engineer, approval by the engineer manager is needed. If the estimated completion date or the statute needs an extension, issue manager and case manager approval is needed. Extending the statute may also require territory manager concurrence. (

) If a new engineering issue is identiﬁed during the examination, a new risk analysis must be completed by the engineer and approved by the engineering team manager. The engineering team manager will coordinate with the case manager to get the issue added in IMS.

a. Coordinate with the team coordinator to set up an initial engineering meeting with the taxpayer or representative. b. Discuss potential issues, potential adjustments, and audit steps with taxpayer. c. Explain the roles of the engineer team manager and engineering manager. d. Exchange expectations. e. Discuss timelines. f. Arrange tours of business operations, interviews or presentations, if needed. g. Issue initial Information Document Requests (IDRs) and discuss the process and expectations. h. Communicate openly with the taxpayer throughout the examination focus on resolving the issues. Resolution should occur at the earliest point possible in the examination.
point possible in the examination. (

) Written requests should be in the form of an IDR. The engineer should the requirements of the team coordinator or referring agent for preparing tracking IDRs. The engineer will offer to meet with the taxpayer or representative to discuss the draft IDR before it is formally presented to taxpayer. (
) When requesting information, the engineer will follow the LB&I IDR contained in IRM

, Information Document Request Process: a. Consider the relevance and reasonableness of the information b. Establish mutually agreeable response dates for individual items if established in an examination plan with the taxpayer. c. Establish priorities. d. Determine taxpayer’s terminology prior to the written request. e. State the purpose of the request. f. Limit the number of items on each IDR. g. Timely follow-up on overdue or incomplete IDR responses and the issue manager if IDR enforcement is required. h. Timely review and notiﬁcation of taxpayer regarding adequacy of responses. i. Follow guidelines set forth in the audit plan j. All IDRs should be entered in IMS and properly tracked as to draft issue date, response date, received date and closed date. k. All late or incomplete IDR responses must follow the LB&I process. (

) The extent of factual development depends on the complexity and risk of the issue. Factual development may include analysis and of the following: • IDR responses and follow-up IDRs • Taxpayer records • Tax returns and supporting tax workpapers • Related returns and entities • Public documents (such as Form
K) Internal Revenue Manual

Written requests should be in the form of an IDR. The engineer should follow the requirements of the team coordinator or referring agent for preparing and tracking IDRs. The engineer will offer to meet with the taxpayer or taxpayer’s representative to discuss the draft IDR before it is formally presented to the taxpayer.
(09-23-2020) Requesting Information from the Taxpayer
When requesting information, the engineer will follow the LB&I IDR procedures contained in IRM 4.46.4.6, Information Document Request Process:

Consider the relevance and reasonableness of the information Establish mutually agreeable response dates for individual items if established in an examination plan with the taxpayer. Establish priorities. Determine taxpayer’s terminology prior to the written request. State the purpose of the request. Limit the number of items on each IDR. Timely follow

up on overdue or incomplete IDR responses and the issue manager if IDR enforcement is required. Timely review and notiﬁcation of taxpayer regarding adequacy of responses. Follow guidelines set forth in the audit plan All IDRs should be entered in IMS and properly tracked as to draft issue date, response date, received date and closed date. All late or incomplete IDR responses must follow the LB&I process.

) The engineer may tour the taxpayer’s plant, property, laboratory, or other ties. When conducting site visits, engineers may hold meetings with personnel. Engineers are required to document site visits and interviews taxpayer personnel in their workpapers. (
) During the examination, engineers may consult with: • Other team members • SMEs • Counsel • Outside consultants (

) The engineer should conduct research, using the following sources: a. Internal Revenue Code and regulations b. Revenue rulings and revenue procedures c. Additional actions may include: a. Involvement of Counsel, if appropriate. b. Consultation with practice network SMEs. c. Discussions of concerns and potential adjustments with issue manager. d. The engineer should analyze the information gathered in an objective manner and accurately apply tax laws to provide tax determinations that are well
supported and documented. As new facts are developed during the examination, the engineer should re
evaluate the scope and depth of examining the issue and adjust as the facts and circumstances dictate.

) Share ﬁndings with the taxpayer with the objective of resolving the issue at earliest point possible. (

) Workpapers are the written or electronic records kept by the engineer that provide the principal support for the engineer’s report, document the proce- dures applied, tests performed, information obtained, and explain the conclusions reached in the examination. They should include all the tion necessary to conduct the examination and support the audit results IRM
, Workpapers, and IRM
, Workpapers and Reports Resources). (

) The issue folder should be a quality product. A quality product includes: a. Indexing all supporting notes to the lead sheet. b. Ensuring that handwritten notes are legible. c. Dating the workpapers for the day the work was completed. d. Cross-referencing workpapers to the activity record. e. Including all relevant information gathered during the examination as workpapers. (

) Supporting workpapers will document the audit trail. These documents may include photographs, documents provided by the taxpayer, documents from third party sources, and correspondence from the taxpayer. (
) The engineer will maintain an activity record in IMS (Form
, Examining Officer’s Activity Record) on the assigned case. The activity record will document actions taken on the case (IRM

) If possible, each issue should be resolved as early as possible in the tion. Thorough factual development by the engineer may facilitate issue resolution. Determine who has authority to resolve issues within the organization. The issue manager and case manager should collaborate on issues before discussing possible resolution with the taxpayer. Engineer managers will ensure that all necessary steps are taken to resolve the where possible. The engineer team manager will elevate the issue to the engineer territory manager when appropriate. (

) Resolution of valuation issues includes: a. Communicating a clear understanding of the taxpayer’s and legal and factual arguments. b. Explaining to the taxpayer why their value is incorrect or c. Considering the acceptable range of values for resolution purposes. d. Proposing the value to the taxpayer that is the most probable and portable. (

) Resolution of non-valuation issues should be addressed by: a. Communicating a clear understanding of the taxpayer’s legal and arguments b. Attempting to reach agreement on the facts c. Attempting to reach agreement on the applicable law (
) If issues are not resolved: a. Issue an Acknowledgment of Facts (AOF) IDR with draft Form
-A all potentially unagreed issues and consider any new and/or disputed facts before issuing the Notice of Proposed Adjustment (Form
) the taxpayer. b. Draft a rebuttal to taxpayer’s protest response. c. Support or present the examination position in Appeals or Fast Track. (

) Upon the completion of an assignment, the engineer will promptly prepare submit a report of ﬁndings and recommendations to the engineer team manager for review. The issue manager will review and approve the report before forwarding the report to the requesting examiner. When writing the report, the engineer should clearly indicate the basis for the recommended justment. Place emphasis on: a. Deﬁning the issue. b. Developing the facts accurately. c. Avoiding lengthy discussions of case law and legal arguments. d. Rebutting the taxpayer’s position. e. Writing in a business style using the ﬁrst person. f. Using plain language and eliminating technical language or jargon wherever possible. (

) The engineer report is the ﬁnal work product of the engineer’s involvement an issue. In most cases, the engineer’s ﬁndings and recommendations will an issue narrative. All reports must be reviewed and approved (or signed) the engineer/issue team manager before they are provided to the

Each proposed issue will be developed and presented to the on a Form
, Notice of Proposed Adjustment. Every engineering report must be reviewed by the engineer team manager. Every Form

must approved (or signed) by the issue manager before it is presented to the coordinator, case manager, or revenue agent. A table of contents and executive summary should be included if appropriate or at the judgment of engineer team manager. As a rule of thumb, if report is more than ten table of contents is recommended and if the report is unagreed, an summary is recommended. If the report has exhibits, a list of exhibits or at- tachments will follow the conclusion. (
) The content will follow this format provided in IRM
, Explanation of Items: a. Issue b. Facts c. Applicable Law d. Taxpayer’s Position e. Argument or Analysis f. Conclusion (

) The ﬁrst section, “Issue”, will frame the issue with a brief conclusion of the results of the examination. Engineering (

) The “Facts” section discusses the facts of the issue developed during the amination. State the relevant facts of the issue that establish the proper tax treatment of the issue. In addition, a brief description of the taxpayer’s business may help a reader understand the context of the issue. The of an examination is to correctly apply the law to the facts. Do not include justments or analysis (including legal analysis) of the issue in the Facts section. The use of sub-headers and tables or charts is helpful for the facts. (

) The discussion of “Applicable Law” will contain the commissioner’s position established by the Internal Revenue Code, treasury regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures and relevant court cases. Technical advice randums, ﬁeld service advice, private letter rulings, and other similar publications may not be cited unless the document is speciﬁc to the and the issue under examination. Speciﬁc case citations may be used if the examiner uses the citations to apply the Code or regulations. Lengthy tions of the Code, regulations, or cited court cases are not helpful. (

) The purpose of the “Taxpayer’s Position” section is to explain what legal pretation the taxpayer relied upon to support their position on the issue. If taxpayer does not provide a clear explanation of their position, this section include a discussion of the steps taken to obtain the information from the taxpayer. If possible, consider including a direct quote from either a response to an IDR or from a study prepared for the issue. (

) The “Argument” or “Analysis” section supports the Commissioner’s position and refutes the taxpayer’s position. The narrative should be persuasive in nature and tie together the facts and law and summarize the applicable law. There should be enough information to tell a story. The narrative will be well organized. The purpose is to explain the disagreement with the taxpayer provide the speciﬁc reasons for the proposed adjustment. One of the of this section is to provide the engineer’s response to the taxpayer’s The narrative should be objective and professional. If technical information necessary, use a plain English explanation of the item in the narrative. Use footnotes to describe or deﬁne technical terms. Do not introduce facts that were not previously discussed in the “Facts” section. (
) The “Conclusion” section brieﬂy summarizes the results of the examination and the reasons for the proposed adjustment. (

) Write the issue narrative using prescribed standards for grammar, wording, erences, quotations, and other style elements. The IRS Style Guide helps writers maintain consistent and uniform standards in communications. (

) Report the results of appraisals of properties or valuations of interests using professional appraisal or valuation report standards. If the appraiser signs a report using a designated certiﬁcation (CVA, ASA, MAI, etc.), the report will comply with the requirements of the certifying organization. Otherwise, the report will comply with the appropriate valuation guidelines contained in IRM
through IRM
) Expert reports may be prepared for non-valuation issues as necessary or requested. (
) Appeals or Counsel may request that an engineer prepare an expert report preparation for litigation. As with any other written work product, the Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
Z
Appeals or Counsel may request that an engineer prepare an expert report in preparation for litigation. As with any other written work product, the engineer

page team manager will review and approve the expert report prior to submission the requestor. This step is necessary to ensure the expert report is accurate and is consistent with policy and procedures. This report may be presented to the court as an expert witness report. Generally, the expert must present the facts. It must be free of subjectivity and unfounded The expert report must not advocate any interpretation of the facts as they may apply to the law or any application of the law. If the engineer is the report should conform to the speciﬁcations or requirements of the organization. It is the responsibility of the engineer to provide the best to the requesting client by ensuring that the expert report complies with the Federal Rules of Evidence, Article VII. The Engineering Training Program is a comprehensive program designed to provide training for the newly hired engineer through the senior level Mandatory recruit training (Phases
through

) includes both in-house and out-service training. This program consists of: a. Orientation (which is offered as Flexible Blended Learning provided by the New Hire Community of Practice) b. Classroom instruction c. Self-instruction material d. Out-service-training Engineering Phase Training Program is as follows: • Phase
– Financial Accounting for Engineers • Phase
– General Administration • Phase
– Technical Topics • Phase
– Appraisal and Business Valuation for Engineers • Phase
– NACVA Case Study and CVA Certiﬁcation External training courses are available from several sources. An approved

, Request, Authorization, Agreement, and Certiﬁcate of Training, is before external training may begin. Some training sources include: a. American Institute of Mining Engineering b. American Petroleum Institute c. American Society of Appraisers d. Appraisal Institute e. Colorado School of Mines f. National Association of Certiﬁed Valuators and Analysts (NACVA) g. Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE) Internal education courses are available from a variety of sources, including the Integrated Talent Management system. Approval from the engineering manager is needed before the courses are to begin.
